application_type_full: Tree works: Trees in conservation areas/subject to TPOs
description: Rear left gardenT1	Cypress x 1	Small self seeded Cypress:		- fell and grind out stump to a depth of 300mmT2	Cypress x 1	Reduce height by 3m and cut back 0.4m to create hedgeT3	Cypress x 1	Reduce height by 3m and cut back 0.4m to  create hedgeT4	Unknown x 1	Stone dead, fell and grind out stump to 	allow flowerbed to be usedT6	Hazel x 1 (Corylus avellana) Previously coppiced hazel. Regrowth cannot be pruned to make attractive and space can be used to plant something of greater ecological value. Suggested work:	- fell and grind out stumpRear left garden lawnT5	Unknown x 1	Dead stump - grind outRear gardenT7	Photina spp x 1 - Reduce height by 1-1.5m		- reduce lateral growth by 0.5m	- thin and reshapeT8	Willow x 1 (Salix spp) Fallen swamp Willow. Suggested work:	- fell and remove	- dig out root ballBottom of rear gardenT9-T12	Cypress x 4	This line of four Cypresses and red Cedars act as a privacy barrier to the top windows of the rear neighbour's house. But they have got so tall now they are cutting out a significant amount of sunlight from the clients garden.  Suggested work:	- reduce height uniformly by 2.5-3m	- cut back toward boundary by 0.5-2m to create a uniformed shape.T13	Holly x 1	(Ilex aquifolium) Reduce height by 3m and shape into hedge with neighbour's bay treeT14	Beech x 1 (Fagus sylvatica)	- Full crown reduction		- Reduce height by 2m	- Reduce laterally by 1.5-2mT16	Cherry x 1 (Prunus spp) Cherry in poor condition, prune to encourage growth	- Reduce height by 1m	- reduce laterally by 1-2m	- deadwood crownT22	Buddleia x 1	Overgrown Buddleia	- fell and dig outT23	Cypress x 1	Fell and grind out	Rear garden - bottom rightT15	Elder x 1	(Sambucus nigra)  Reduce height by 3-4m to make nearby beech more prominent, whilst retaining privacy screen to neighbour's trampoline area.Rear garden lawnT21	Unknown x 1	small dead stump - grind outRear right gardenT17-T19	Cypress x 3	This line of Cypresses and red cedars need to be red...
